At this point, Dutt has a second half-verse that is said to be reconstructed from the Tibetan and absent in the Sanskrit (although these lines are not present in the Degé, their absence is not noted in the Pedurma, and they are not present in the Stok Palace): “When it comes time to die, / it is similarly fruitful for him.” The commentary does not gloss any of these verses. Here, the Chinese has: “In this way, after hearing the Dharma / He develops the Dharma he has heard. / He remembers it constantly, / Day and night, without intermission.”
“The Tathāgata who has engaged in diligence,
Gaining accomplishments for numerous eons,
Has taught to the bodhisattvas
These benefits of possessing diligence.
“He who engages in diligence
Is in the care of the jinas.
The devas, too, make aspirations for him.
He will soon attain the Buddha’s enlightenment.
“What he has learned will never diminish,
And he gives many other Dharma teachings.
His confidence of speech increases immensely.
Those are the benefits of engaging in diligence.
“He will quickly attain the lineage of samādhis.
He will never become ill.
Whatever food he eats
He will comfortably digest completely.
“Day and night the good qualities
Of his powerful diligence increase.
Through the power of this diligence,
Before long he will attain enlightenment.”

“Young man, there are ten benefits for the bodhisattva mahāsattva from being devoted to meditation. What are the ten benefits? They are: [1] he maintains his bodhisattva conduct; [2] he engages in the field of that conduct; The commentary states that this refers to “the levels, the six perfections, and so forth.” The Chinese has “engages in the field of loving kindness,” 行慈境界. [3] he lives free from anguish; [4] his sensory faculties are protected; According to the commentary, this means that in a state of meditation the senses are disengaged from their objects. Chinese has “protected,” 守護 (shou hu). [5] he experiences pleasure; Chinese: “bliss without food.” “Without food” is a synonym for the meditative state. [6] he is separated from desire; [7] he has insatiability for meditation; [8] he is free from the domain of Māra; [9] he is established in the domain of the Buddha; and [10] he ripens the state of liberation.
“Young man, those are the ten benefits for the bodhisattva mahāsattva from being devoted to meditation.”
On this topic, it was said:
“He is never without bodhisattva conduct,
As he is established in bodhisattva conduct.
The yogin practices the field of that conduct,
And rejects that which is not the field of that conduct.
“He lives without anguish.
His senses hidden and bound,
He experiences pleasure.
His field of conduct is practicing meditation.
“He is without desire, or the craving of desire.
He abides in the bliss of meditation.
He is free from the domain of Māra
And dwells in the Buddha’s domain.
“This is the particular quality of the yogin:
That he delights in being alone in the forest.
He brings liberation to fruition.
Those are the ten aspects.
“The bodhisattva remains in bodhisattva conduct
And he rejects everything that is not that conduct.
He rejects that which is not the field of that conduct and remains in that which is.
Those are the benefits of endeavoring in samādhi.
“He never experiences anguish.
He reaches the state of higher bliss.
Both his body and mind become blissful.

These are the benefits of endeavoring in meditation. The Tibetan here has bsam gtan (as in the prose opening on this topic), while the Sanskrit has samādhi both here and in the last line of the preceding verse.
“He lives secretly in solitary places.
He never has any distractions.
Thus his body is in isolation
And he attains happiness free of desires.
“He is unstained by desires and has no kleśas.
Thus he is free from the domain of Māra
And is established in the domain of the tathāgatas.
He brings his liberation to fruition.”

“Young man, there are ten benefits for the bodhisattva mahāsattva from engaging in wisdom. What are these ten? They are: [1] he gives away all his possessions without becoming proud that he is pure; [2] he has immaculate, correct conduct without forming an attachment to that conduct; [3] he maintains the power of patience without maintaining the conceptualization that there are beings; [4] he takes up diligence in isolation from body and mind; According to the commentary, this means that there is no conceptualized fixation upon the diligent activity of body, speech, or mind. [5] in meditating he meditates with a non-abiding meditation; [6] he is invincible to the māras; [7] he is unshakable to all adversaries; Chinese: “His mind cannot be swayed by other views,” 於他言論其心不動 (yu ta yan lun qi xin bu dong). [8] he attains illumination regarding all engagement with the composite; The commentary explains that involvement with the composite is like darkness and the bodhisattva’s wisdom is like a light that eliminates that darkness. The Chinese here has: 能達生死海底 (neng da sheng si hai), literally, “he has reached the bottom of the ocean of life and death,” which means, “he knows the depth of the ocean of saṃsāra” or “he transcends saṃsāra.” [9] with vast great compassion for all, and without any aspiration for the level of the śrāvakas or pratyekabuddhas; These two qualities are the ninth and tenth benefits in the Chinese. and [10] he enters into the dhyānas, samādhis, and samāpattis of the buddhas. This does not appear in the Chinese.
“Young man, those are the ten benefits for the bodhisattva mahāsattva from engaging in wisdom.”
On this topic, it was said:
“The heroic one gives away all his possessions
But does not become proud that he is pure.
He keeps his correct conduct immaculate
But he forms no attachment to that.
“The wise one meditates on patience
But has expelled the conceptualization of beings.
He is someone who engages in diligence
But in isolation from body and mind.
“He is one who cultivates meditation,
But without abiding and independent;
He is invincible to the māras.
Those are the qualities of one who has wisdom.
“He is unshakable
To every adversary
And has obtained the illumination of saṃsāra.
Those are the qualities of wisdom.
“He has attained great compassion
Toward all beings.
He never has an aspiration
For the wisdom of the śrāvaka or pratyekabuddha.
“He is not proud of being pure through giving away all his possessions.
He has immaculate correct conduct but has no attachment to conduct.
He meditates on patience but has no conceptualization of beings.
Those are the benefits of being devoted to wisdom.
“He engages in diligence but in isolation. According to the Tibetan and Chinese. Here the Sanskrit has vimukta (“liberation”) instead of the earlier vivikta (“isolation”).
He meditates without being bound, without fixation.

He is wise “Wise” does not appear in the Chinese. and is invincible to Māra. According to the Sanskrit, here māra is in the singular, while earlier it was in the plural. Neither is indicated in the Tibetan or Chinese.
Those are the benefits of being devoted to wisdom.
“He is unshakable to adversaries. Chinese: “He is unswayed by other views.”

He has discovered the shallowness According to the Sanskrit gādha. The Tibetan has gting, “depth.” The Chinese uses the expression, “have reached the bottom of (the ocean of) life and death (compare n. 918),” to mean “knowing the depth of samsara, or the composite.” Gādha translated into Chinese can mean “shallowness” or “depth.” of the composite,
And he has vast compassion for beings.
Those are the benefits of being devoted to wisdom.
“He never gives rise to an aspiration to be
A pratyekabuddha or śrāvaka,
And thus he is established in the qualities of a buddha.
Those are the benefits of being devoted to wisdom. Chinese: “faith and wisdom.”

“Young man, there are ten benefits for the bodhisattva mahāsattva from becoming very learned. What are the ten benefits? They are: [1] he does not create kleśas; Chinese: “He knows the kleśas.” [2] he does not develop malice; Chinese: “He knows purification.” [3] he exposes doubts; [4] he makes views accurate; [5] he shuns the wrong paths; [6] he is established on the true path; [7] he has reached the doorway to deathlessness; [8] he is close to enlightenment; [9] he is a light for beings; and [10] he has no fear of the lower existences.
“Young man, those are the ten benefits for the bodhisattva mahāsattva from becoming very learned.”
On this topic, it was said:
“These are taught to be the ten benefits
From becoming very learned
Just as they are known
By the Tathāgata, the Buddha.
“He knows the two aspects
Of the kleśas and of purification.
He rejects the kleśas
And follows According to the Sanskrit pratiṣthate (“to be upon”) and the Yonglé and Peking Kangyur sten (“to rely upon”). The Degé has ston (“teach”). the path of purification.
“The wise one rejects doubts
And develops accurate views.
He shuns the wrong path
And follows the correct path.
“He is at the door to deathlessness
And he is close to enlightenment.
He is a light for beings
And he is not afraid of the lower existences.
“He knows the numerous properties of having the kleśas,
And in the same way he knows the aspect of purification.
He completely rejects the kleśas
And trains in the supreme quality of purification.
“He exposes the doubts of all beings.
He has a view that is always accurate.
He shuns the wrong path
And is always upon the true path of peace.
“He is always beside the doorway to deathlessness;
He is always close to stainless enlightenment.
He has become a light to all the multitudes of beings
And he has no fear of the lower existences.

“Young man, for the bodhisattva mahāsattva who is intent on giving the Dharma, there are ten benefits that come from giving the Dharma. What are the ten benefits? They are: [1] he rejects that which should not be done; [2] he engages in that which should be done; [3] he follows the Dharma of a worthy person; [4] he purifies buddha realms; [5] he reaches the Bodhimaṇḍa; [6] he gives away material things; [7] he overcomes the kleśas; [8] he gives his portion The commentary explains that this means that he dedicates the merit he has to the beings who do not have that merit. The Chinese translates as “portion of merit.” to all beings; [9] he meditates on love toward those on whom his mind is focused; and [10] he attains happiness in this life.
“Young man, for the bodhisattva mahāsattva who is intent on giving the Dharma, those are the ten benefits that come from giving the Dharma.”
On this topic, it was said:
“He who gives the supreme gift,
The gift of the Dharma, is not a miser.
The Lord of the World has taught
That he will have ten benefits.
“He rejects all that should not be done;
The wise one engages in what should be done.
He obtains the Dharma of a worthy person
And maintains a motivation of generosity.
“He purifies a buddha realm. According to the Sanskrit singular form. The Chinese has “realms.”
His realm is inconceivable. According to the later Sanskrit manuscripts and the Tibetan. The Gilgit has “the highest.” Chinese: “as the Buddha has taught.”
He is always on the Bodhimaṇḍa, According to the Tibetan. The Sanskrit bodhimaṇḍaṃ samārūḍha means “He has taken his seat upon the Bodhimaṇḍa.”
Which is the result of giving the Dharma.
He gives away all material things.
He follows the king of the Dharma.
For he who has overcome the kleśas,
Enlightenment is not hard to attain.
With a loving mind he gives
His portion to all beings.
He is someone who has no envy,
And he has a happiness higher than that of humans.
He is a learned man who rejects what should not be done.
He is a wise man who is always doing what should be done.
He always follows the Dharma of great beings.
He is a learned man who always gives the gift of the Dharma.
His realm is one that is always pure.
He increases those qualities that are aspects of enlightenment.
He is always close to the Bodhimaṇḍa.
Those are the benefits of giving the Dharma.
He has no kleśas, and gives material things away.
He knows the characteristics of things.
He is liberated from all attachment.
He never has any impediments.
He has a wise man’s mind.
He wishes for all beings to be happy.
He has a loving mind free of envy,
And in this life his happiness is not little.

“Young man, there are ten benefits for the bodhisattva mahāsattva who dwells in emptiness. What are the ten benefits? They are: [1] he dwells in the dwelling of the Buddha; According to the commentary, the dwelling of the Buddha is emptiness. [2] his meditation is nondwelling; According to the Tibetan mi gnas pa. The BHS aniśrita and the Chinese could be translated as “nondependent.” [3] he is not intent on rebirth; The Chinese adds “of any kind.” [4] he has no clinging to conduct; According to the Sanskrit parmāṛṣati and the Chinese於戒不取 (yu jie bu qu). Translated into Tibetan as mchog tu ’ dzin pa (literally, “holding as supreme”). According to the commentary this means there is freedom from the concepts of a self who maintains conduct, a conduct that is being maintained, and a goal that is to be achieved through that conduct. Śīlavrataparāmarśa (tshul khrims dang brtul zhugs mchog tu ’dzin pa), “clinging to conduct and observance,” is one of the four kinds of attachment (upādana, len pa) as well as one of the ten fetters (saṃyojana, kun tu sbyor ba). [5] he does not criticize superior beings; [6] he lives in an appropriate manner; [7] he does not conceptualize the objects of perception; Commentary: “he sees the empty nature of all things.” Chinese: “he is without conflict.” [8] he remains detached; According to the commentary: “he remains in the meditation of emptiness, which is detached, separate, or isolated from all kleśas.” Chinese: “detached from all bad matters.” [9] he does not disparage the buddhas; According to the commentary, disparaging the Buddha means claiming that the Buddha’s true teaching was the existence of individuals, and so on, instead of the emptiness of all phenomena. and [10] he possesses the Dharma. Chinese: “all white, pure Dharma.”
“Young man, those are the ten benefits for the bodhisattva mahāsattva who dwells in emptiness.”
On this topic, it was said:
“The yogin dwells in that which is
The dwelling of the lords of men
And the field of activity of all the buddhas,
Without the conception of a life.
“Without dependence on any existence
He never gives up the superior dhyāna.
Having seen the nature of phenomena
He has no intention of being reborn.
“He who has no clinging to conduct
Will not be dependent on conduct. Chinese: “has immaculate conduct,” 成就無漏戒 (cheng jiu wu lou jie), from anāsravaśīla.
He does not criticize in any way another

Another superior being According to the Sanskrit and the prose section. The Tibetan adds “path” here, making it the superior, or noble, path rather than a superior being. who is without defilement. The Chinese has a different version of the second half of the verse: “He will not be born in lower realms, 不生惡道中 (bu sheng yu er dao zhong) / And will always remain within noble families常安住聖種 (chang an zhu sheng zhong).”
“He lives in an appropriate manner
And is not known to quarrel.
The yogin does not conceptualize things
But lives always detached.
“He does not disparage the Buddha
Even for the sake of his life.
While remaining in the emptiness of phenomena
He is fearlessly visible in his body.
“He teaches the Dharma with veneration
For the inconceivable enlightenment of buddhahood
Of all the lords of the worlds,
And he has no doubt in the Dharma of the Buddha.
“The dwelling place of the supreme individuals,
The level not that of the many kinds of tīrthika,
There where there is no being, soul, or person:
That is where the bodhisattva dwells. Chinese: “There is no fixation on the bliss of dhyāna,” 不依禪定樂 (bu yi chan ding le).
“He has no dwelling whatsoever.
He remains in the bliss of nondwelling dhyāna. Sanskrit: aniśrita (“non-dependent”). Chinese: “teachings on emptiness.”
He sees that phenomena have no self, no being,
And he does not give rise to the concept of creation.
“He understands the nature of phenomena.
He has no dependence even on conduct.
He does not conceive of himself as pure because of conduct,
And always has faith in the buddhas. According to the Tibetan. The Sanskrit has āryas (the superior, noble ones). The Chinese has “buddhas and āryas” (佛勝人, fo sheng ren).
“He meditates on the empty nature of all phenomena
And he is never in any way inappropriate.
He possesses the pure Dharma of the tathāgatas
And does not disparage the guides.

“Young man, there are ten benefits for the bodhisattva mahāsattva who remains intently in meditative seclusion. What are the ten benefits? They are: [1] his mind is unpolluted; [2] he remains careful; [3] he keeps the Buddha in mind; [4] he has faith in bodhisattva conduct; According to the Sanskrit and Tibetan. The commentary, however, has chos (“Dharma”) instead of the similarly sounding spyod (“conduct”). However, the definition of it as both “realization” and “scriptural transmission” indicates that it was “Dharma” in the Sanskrit commentary. [5] he has no uncertainty concerning wisdom; According to the commentary: “he does not have any doubt as to whether the Buddha’s wisdom exists, or his ability to attain it.” Chinese: “wisdom of the Buddha.” [6] he has gratitude toward the buddhas; According to the commentary this means engaging in looking at the Buddha, paying homage to him, making offerings to him, and so on, as a result of knowing the qualities that come from hearing, contemplating, and meditating on the Dharma. The Chinese has only “he has gratitude.” [7] he does not abandon Chinese: “disparage,” 謗 (bang). the Dharma; [8] he maintains vows perfectly; [9] he has attained the level of self-discipline; and [10] he has the direct perception of the four discernments.
“Young man, those are the ten benefits for the bodhisattva mahāsattva who remains intently in meditative seclusion.”
On this topic, it was said:
“His mind is unpolluted.
He has rejected all carelessness.
He maintains carefulness.
His field of activity is meditative seclusion.
“He has faith in the buddhas, having heard
Of the conduct of the Lord of the World.
The yogin has no doubt concerning wisdom,
The inconceivable wisdom of the buddhas.
“He has gratitude toward the buddhas,
And has no doubt concerning the Dharma of the buddhas.
He maintains his vows perfectly,
And has attained the level of self-discipline.
“He has attained discernment.
He delights in being alone in the forest.
He has forsaken gain and honors,
And his field of activity is meditative seclusion.
“His mind is unpolluted.
He has forsaken all carelessness.
He is a great being who is always careful.
Those are the benefits of being dedicated to samādhi.
“He keeps in mind the buddhas, the supreme humans,
And he has faith in their supreme conduct.
He does not doubt the wisdom of the tathāgatas.
Those are the benefits of being dedicated to samādhi.
“He always has gratitude toward the buddhas.
He does not forsake the Dharma even for the sake of his life.
At all times he keeps his vows perfectly.
Those are the benefits of being dedicated to samādhi.
“He has attained the level of self-discipline.
He quickly attains the direct perception of discernment.
He speaks with the unceasing confidence of speech.
He teaches millions and billions of sūtras.
“He quickly attains the enlightenment of buddhahood.
He protects the teaching of the Guide.
He defeats all who are adversaries.
He extensively propagates the enlightenment of buddhahood.
“When that bodhisattva passes away,
He goes to the realm of Sukhāvatī.
He hears the highest Dharma from Amitāyus
And attains the acceptance of the nonorigination of phenomena.

“Young man, there are ten benefits for the bodhisattva mahāsattva who is dedicated to solitude. What are the ten benefits? They are: [1] he has few activities; [2] he has gone far from busy crowds; [3] he has no quarrels; [4] he has no harm; [5] he does not increase defilements; According to the commentary these are the kleśas and karma that arise from ignorance, aversion, and attachment. [6] he does not create any cause for disputes; [7] he has perfectly peaceful conduct; [8] he maintains perfect self-restraint; [9] his mind is prepared for liberation; and [10] he quickly manifests liberation.
“Young man, those are the ten benefits for the bodhisattva mahāsattva who is dedicated to solitude.”
On this topic, it was said:
“He always has few activities.
He has gone far from busy crowds.
He has no quarrels.
He lives alone in the forest.
“Without an intention to cause harm
He does not increase his defilements.
He has no cause for disputes.
Those are the qualities of living in a forest.
“He is peaceful in his conduct.
He restrains his body, speech, and mind.
He is prepared for liberation;
He will quickly reach liberation.
“He is a yogin who always has few activities.
He has shunned the many faults of busy gatherings.
The yogin According to the Sanskrit, which is in the singular, as in the other lines, though the Tibetan has the plural. does not ever quarrel.
Those are the qualities of living in a solitary place.
“When he has become saddened by the composite,
He never harbors any longing for the world,
And he does not increase his defilements.
The one who lives in a forest gains these benefits.
“There never arises in him a cause for disputes.
He lives in solitude, delighting in peace.
His body, speech, and mind are restrained.
The one who lives in solitude will have many qualities.
“He is prepared for liberation.
He will quickly attain the peace of liberation.
He dwells in the forest and is close to liberation.
One who dwells in solitude will have all these qualities.

“Young man, there are ten benefits for the bodhisattva mahāsattva who lives by receiving alms in the austerity of the disciplines of mendicancy. What are the ten benefits? They are: [1] he has no desire for a reputation; [2] he has no desire for fame; [3] he has no desire for honors or gains; [4] he remains within the four noble families; According to the commentary, this means the four noble truths. The Chinese does not have “four.” [5] he has no hypocrisy or boasting; [6] he does not praise himself; [7] he does not criticize others; [8] he engages with households without aversion or attachment; According to the commentary, this is referring to “households from which he receives food on his alms rounds, maintaining equanimity or impartiality toward them all.” Chinese: “he is devoid of attachment and aversion.” [9] he gives the Dharma without expectation of a reward; According to the Sanskrit nirāmiṣa and the commentary. The Tibetan translates vaguely as zang zing (material goods). Āmiṣa can mean gifts in general and also specifically food. The Chinese integrates this into the previous point. Chinese: “He teaches the Dharma without expectation of food.” and [10] the Dharma he teaches while remaining in the austerity of the disciplines of mendicancy will be remembered.
“Young man, those are the ten benefits for the bodhisattva mahāsattva who lives by receiving alms in the austerity of the disciplines of mendicancy.”
On this topic, it was said:
“He has no desire for a reputation.
He does not wish for fame.
He who remains in the disciplines of mendicancy
Is indifferent to gain and loss.
“He does not abandon the noble family.
He has no hypocrisy or boastfulness.
He does not praise himself
And he does not criticize others.
“He has no attachment or aversions,
And teaches the Dharma with no thought of reward.
The words he speaks will be remembered.
A recipient of alms will have those qualities. Chinese: “These are the qualities of austere mendicancy.”
“He does not seek reputation, fame, or gain.
He remains within the four noble families.
The wise one is neither hypocritical nor boastful.
Those are the qualities of dedication to mendicancy.
“He does not praise himself or criticize others.
He is not upset when spoken to harshly.
He is not delighted when he hears himself praised.
A recipient of alms will have that contentment. Chinese: “These are the qualities of austere mendicancy.”
“He gives the gift of the Dharma without thought of reward.
He does not search for fame or gain.
The words he speaks will be remembered.
Those are the benefits that come from dedication to mendicancy.

“Young man, the bodhisattva mahāsattva who dwells in solitude while maintaining those qualities of the Dharma will obtain the treasure of the buddhas, he will obtain the treasure of the Dharma, he will obtain the treasure of wisdom, and he will obtain the treasure of knowing the past, the future, and the present.

“Young man, how does the bodhisattva mahāsattva obtain the treasure of the buddhas? Young man, the bodhisattva mahāsattva who practices alone, who dwells in solitude, will attain the five higher cognitions. What are the five higher cognitions? They are divine sight, divine hearing, the knowledge of others’ minds, remembering past lives, and possessing miraculous powers. Young man, those are the five higher cognitions that are obtained. Through divine vision, which transcends human vision, the countless, innumerable buddha bhagavāns in the eastern direction are seen. In the same way the countless, innumerable buddha bhagavāns in the southern, western, and northern directions are seen. He constantly has this vision of the buddhas. Young man, in that way the bodhisattva mahāsattva obtains the treasure of the buddhas.

“Young man, how does the bodhisattva mahāsattva obtain the treasure of the Dharma? The bodhisattva mahāsattva hears with his divine hearing the Dharma that is taught by those buddha bhagavāns in the ten directions. He is constantly hearing the Dharma. Young man, in that way the bodhisattva mahāsattva obtains the treasure of the Dharma.

“Young man, how does the bodhisattva mahāsattva obtain the treasure of wisdom? Young man, the bodhisattva mahāsattva who has that wisdom obtains the entire Dharma. He does not forget anything that he has obtained, and teaches the Dharma to beings, knowing what will be beneficial for any one person. Young man, in that way the bodhisattva mahāsattva obtains the treasure of wisdom.

“Young man, how does the bodhisattva mahāsattva obtain the treasure of knowing the past, the future, and the present? Through the higher cognitions he gains the knowledge of the minds and conduct of all beings in the past, the future, and the present. Young man, in that way the bodhisattva mahāsattva obtains the treasure of knowing the past, the future, and the present.

“Young man, in brief, the bodhisattva mahāsattva who maintains the qualities of the Dharma in that way will obtain the entire Dharma of the buddhas. This level is not reached by śrāvakas or pratyekabuddhas, let alone any adversary of the Dharma.”
On this topic, it was said:
“The wise one who remains in solitude
Will quickly attain the treasure of the buddhas,
The treasure of the Dharma, the treasure of wisdom,
The treasure of the past, and the five higher cognitions.” This verse is absent in the Chinese.
Conclusion of the twenty-ninth chapter, “Ten Benefits.”

div.head: Chapter 30: Tejaguṇarāja
div.p: Then the Bhagavān said to the youth Candraprabha, “Therefore, young man, you should train in this way, thinking, ‘I will abandon even the pleasures of the kingship of a divine cakravartin and enter homelessness.’
“Young man, having entered homelessness you should maintain the disciplines of mendicancy, live in solitude, and develop perfect mildness and patience.

“Young man, you should apply yourself diligently, as if your hair and clothes were on fire, and listen to the samādhi, the revealed equality of the nature of all phenomena, learn it, understand it, keep it, recite it to others, promote it, proclaim it, chant it, meditate on it with unadulterated meditation, promulgate it, and make it widely known to others.
“Young man, you should always, like a rhinoceros, dwell without a companion in the forest.” The beginning of this chapter, up to this point, is absent in the Chinese.

Thereupon the Bhagavān, in order to explain this topic, “In order to explain this topic” does not appear in the Chinese. gave a detailed teaching on this episode from the past by chanting the following verses to the youth Candraprabha:
“I remember many hundreds of eons ago
There was a guide of limitless renown.
Multitudes of humans, devas, and nāgas made offerings to him.
He was a jina named Tejaguṇarāja.
“During that time there formed a community
Of a hundred and sixty million bhikṣus with higher cognitions,
Who had completely attained the power of the discernments,
Who practiced the austerity of the disciplines of mendicancy, and who had peaceful minds.
“At that time there were in this Jambudvīpa
One billion seven hundred and sixty million towns,
And each of them was five yojanas wide,
And was particularly supreme, made of the seven precious materials.
“At that time, all of those perfect towns
Were adorned by many hundreds of parks,
And all those parks were adorned
With fresh flowers and fruit, like massed clouds.
“Those perfect parks were adorned
With various beautiful trees with edible fruits—
Covered with jackfruits, mangos, rose apples, and breadfruit,
And with hundreds of karnikara, magnolia, and punnaga trees.
“At that time, flocks of birds in banyan trees would sing—
Hundreds of cuckoos, avadavats, and peacocks,
And flocks of many other birds were heard:
The songs of parrots, According to the Sanskrit. Absent in the Tibetan. partridges, and snipes.
“There was the supreme sound of the songs of bees and partridges

That equaled that of Dhṛtarāṣṭra, This is a reference to the Haṃsajātaka, the story of the Buddha’s previous life as a goose king named Dhṛtarāṣṭra who taught the Dharma to a king and queen. the king of geese.
They had bright, multicolored bodies, brilliant with great hues,
And sang delightful, beautiful, charming songs.
“At that time, there were gatherings of these birds,
There were the songs of avadavats, peacocks, and parrots, According to the Tibetan. The Sanskrit vihaga is usually a generic word for “birds.”
Cuckoos, mynas, and a variety of other birds—
Various kinds of songs from many birds.
“They dwelt in those hundreds of parks
Where there were the blossoms of karnikara,
Gardenia, ashoka, and kachnar trees,
As well as red lotuses, blue lotuses, night lotuses, and white lotuses.
“They were beautified by lotus flower ponds
That were adorned by a hundred thousand lotuses.
There were beautiful, exquisite lotus ponds
Adorned by the fragrance of the most delightful scents.
“At that time, the king in this Jambudvīpa
Was the lord of men whose name was Dṛdhadatta.
He had five hundred sons
Who were handsome and beautiful to see.
“At that time the kingdom was peaceful and happy,
Free of calamities, and filled with joy and peace.
Jambudvīpa was adorned by many flowers.
It was identical to a paradise, with no difference.
“At that time there was a jina, one with the ten strengths,
Without bad actions, who taught this supreme samādhi:
‘The beings within existence are like dreams.
There is no one who is born and no one who dies.

“ ‘There is no being to be found, and no soul, According to the commentary this is referring to the Samkhya view of a puruṣa (“individual”) and his or her jīva (“soul”), which keeps them bound to prakṛti (“nature”). Chinese: “lifespan,” 壽 (shou). or person. According to the Sanskrit nara, Chinese人 (ren), and Yonglé, Peking, Lithang, Narthang, and Cone Kangyurs mi. Degé: ming (“name”).

These phenomena are like dreams According to the Tibetan. The Sanskrit has phena (“foam”), and this is matched by the Tibetan of the commentary (dbu ba). The Tibetan may therefore have been translated according to a variant Sanskrit manuscript not represented today. or a plantain tree; Instead of “dreams / foam or a plantain tree,” the Chinese has “like a wild horse.”
Like illusions, the same as lightning in the sky;

Like the moon on water, the same as a mirage. At this point in the Shastri manuscript there is a verse that begins, “The three realms are like a dream …” which is absent in the Gilgit, Chinese, Tibetan, and the Hodgson manuscript, and yet is quoted by Candrakīrti in the seventh century.
“ ‘There is no person who dies in this world,
Who departs and goes to another world.
But the karma that has been created is not destroyed.
It will ripen as good and bad results within saṃsāra.
“ ‘It is neither eternal nor is it annihilated.
There is no accumulation or presence of karma,
Yet if it has been created there is no way to avoid encountering it,
While that which is created by others will not be experienced.
“ ‘There is no passing away or returning.
There is no existence of all things, yet neither are they nonexistent.
There is no pure engagement with the locus of a view.
There is no conduct of beings and no engagement with peace.
“ ‘The conduct of the sugatas, the qualities of the jinas,
Are birthlessness, peace, and the absence of attributes.
The supreme leaders, the buddhas, have these strengths and retentions,
And the strength of the ten strengths.
“ ‘The supreme good qualities, the accumulation of qualities,
Are the supreme qualities, wisdom, retentions, strengths,
The supreme manifestation of miraculous powers,
And the attainment of the five Chinese: “six.” supreme higher cognitions.
“ ‘There is no essence here to be known whatsoever.

There is no coming, no going; that is the subtle According to the BHS nipuṇa. The Tibetan translates incorrectly according to its classical Sanskrit meaning mkhas pa (wise, or skillful). Absent in the Chinese. mode of phenomena. In this and the following verses, there is much word-play in both Sanskrit and Tibetan between the closely related (see glossary) terms for “movement” or “going” (Sanskrit gati, Tibetan ’gro), and “mode” (Sanskrit gatī, Tibetan ’gros).
The essence of phenomena has no movement whatsoever,
Thus the mode of phenomena is the mode of no movement.
“ ‘The natural mode is not in the accumulation of words.
This mode, this nature, does not dwell anywhere.
The natural mode is without dwelling, is nondependent.
It is the level of peace, the stainless domain of the jinas.
“ ‘It is the mode of peace, complete peace, total peace.
That mode does not dwell anywhere.
It always accompanies the nature of things.

It is subtle, According to the BHS nipuna and the Chinese微細 (wei xi). The Tibetan translates incorrectly according to its classical Sanskrit meaning mkhas pa (“wise,” “skillful”). difficult to see, and an unfluctuating state.
“ ‘It does not fluctuate but continues to be itself.
It is a continuing nature that neither stays nor comes.
This continuing nature cannot be described.
It is the empty, unfluctuating continuity of phenomena.
“ ‘It is taught in words but it is not the mode of words.
The mode of the nature of words is the mode of phenomena.
The aggregation of words has no location anywhere,
And that mode of its nature is the mode of phenomena.
“ ‘The words that describe the mode are not the mode of being.
The nature of phenomena is a mode of subtle Chinese: “true.” meaning.
Though words are spoken, that is not the mode of being;
Words cannot be found and neither can the mode of being.
“ ‘There is no endlessness, nor an end, nor a mode in between.
There is no existence nor nonexistence, nor a partial mode.
The knowledge of that mode of nature
Is the same in the teachings of all the supreme jinas.
“ ‘The stainless, pure, ultimate state—
Peace, complete peace, without stain, free of stain—
There are no concepts or pride in the state of peace
That is taught by the Jina, the one with perfect compassion.
“ ‘In this there is no usage of letters.
It is a vast mode, a vast mode of meaning.
The buddhas honor it; the jinas praise it.
The appearance of the Dharma is a subtle mode.
“ ‘The unequaled sugatas remain in that
Stainless, vast treasure of the Dharma.
They teach the stainless, precious Dharma,

The ultimate truth of emptiness, the subtle According to the Sanskrit nipurṇārtha. The Tibetan has zhi ba’i don (“peaceful meaning”). The Sanskrit nipurṇārtha is sometimes translated into Chinese as “true,” and sometimes as “subtle.” Here it is translated as “mode of true meaning,” 真義道 (zhen yi dao). mode of meaning.’ The Chinese has a different order for this and the preceding three verses.
“When King Dṛdhadatta heard
That the supreme human was teaching this samādhi,

He then According to the Gilgit manuscript tada, and the commentary; does not appear in the Shastri. The Hodgson has sadā, and the Tibetan has translated from sadā as rtag (“always”), which does not seem to fit the context. came into the presence of the compassionate Jina
Accompanied by eighty quintillion others.
“The sovereign over men felt veneration for the Jina
Who was endowed with the strengths, and bowed down to his feet.
While he stayed in front of the one with the ten strengths,
Filled with joy, he placed his ten fingers together in homage.
“The Jina, who was perfect, with control over his senses,
Perceived the king’s pure conduct.
The supreme human knew his aspiration
And taught him this supreme samādhi.
“When the king had heard this ultimate truth
He experienced a vast, superior joy.
He gave up all of the four continents.
He abandoned pleasures and left his home.
“When the king gave up the world and entered homelessness
For the sake of enlightenment and to become a jina,
All the people in this Jambudvīpa Here the synonym “Jambudhvaja” (Jambu Banner) is used. The Chinese has “Jambudvīpa,” 閻浮提 (yan fu ti).
Gave up all sensory pleasures and entered homelessness too.
“At that time there was a vast assembly with the ten strengths.
There were many diligent bhikṣus and bhikṣuṇīs.
At that time, herbs grew without ploughing,
And devas came to serve and attend to them.
“The three orange Dharma robes manifested,
Perfectly cut and sewn, without parallel,
Unsullied, stainless, adorned, beautifully golden,
Arising from the Buddha’s qualities and the power of merit.
“See, young man, look how that supreme king
Gave up the entire world and entered homelessness. In the Chinese there are an additional two lines to make the second half of a verse, about pursuing the bliss of bodhicitta.
In the age of destruction there will be many beings
Who will have few possessions but will not leave their homes. In the Chinese there are an additional two lines to make the second half of a verse, about suffering and lack of faith.
“There will be many in chains and suffering punishments,
Who are abused, threatened, and have unwished-for suffering.

There will be many who will have to endure harm from royal families, According to the Sanskrit and Chinese. The Tibetan has the obscure bla ma yi chad pa, presumably meaning “punishment from on high.”
Who will have very few possessions and no food in their homes.
“They will have very short lives and no wealth.
They will be very careless and have no power of merit.
They will be stupid, and unskilled in any craft.
They will be in poverty with nothing in their homes.
40. Replaced by a different verse in the Chinese.
“They will be impure and desire the wives of others.
They will be envious and extremely rash.
They will be degenerate and behave badly—
Yet they will say, ‘I am going to be a buddha.’
“They will make deceptive promises and be brazen, saying,
‘I am wealthy and I will give the wealth of the Dharma to the world.’ Chinese: “they guard their own fortune but rob others of their wealth.”
They will cause harm, be hypocritical and dishonest—
Yet they will say, ‘I am going to be a buddha.’
“They will delight in killing, binding, and attacking others;
They will have bad conduct, and be cruel and aggressive.
They will have no gratitude, be divisive and violent—
Yet will say, ‘I am a noble practitioner of bodhisattva conduct.’
“They become angry with anyone
Who they hear teaching bodhisattva conduct.
When they hear something that is stupid According to the Sanskrit. The Tibetan has translated as mkhas pa (“wise”). and mistaken

They repeat those blameworthy words a hundred times. Chinese: “When they see a Dharma teacher make a small mistake, / They would exaggerate it and add hundreds or thousands more to it.” 若見法師少過失，增長加說百千種 (ruo jian fa shi shao guo shi, zeng zhang jia shuo bai qian zhong).
“Young man, having heard these words of mine,
Do not follow According to the Tibetan. Sanskrit: “do not praise.” Chinese: “do not get close to,” 勿親近 (wu qin jin). those others.
If you wish to reach the highest enlightenment
They are not to be trusted, even in a dream.
“One could recount for hundreds of eons the many qualities
Ascribed to the austere disciplines of mendicancy,
But without possessing those qualities
One will not attain the peace of the highest enlightenment.
“Always be good and gentle.
Always have pure conduct and a serene mind.
Continually maintain pure conduct,
And before long you will attain the supreme samādhi.
“Do not be proud and do not be harsh.
Always have a mind that is serene.
Eliminate all pride, arrogance, and hiding of your faults,
And attain this supreme samādhi.
“Always remember the Jina’s qualities.
The color of perfect gold, shining brightly,
Like the sky at night filled with stars:
The Sage’s body is filled with signs.
i.
“The descendant of Manu who remembers the moon of the Sage
While walking, sitting, standing, or lying down
Will always have the Teacher present before him,
And he will have vast happiness. According to the Sanskrit nirvrtti. The Tibetan translates as mnya nga las ’ das pa (nirvāṇa). This verse does not appear in the Gilgit manuscript or the Chinese.
“Holding many powders and ointments,
And excellent parasols, banners, canopies, and flags,
Always make offerings to the Sugata
And this supreme samādhi will soon be attained.
“Holding many musical instruments
And excellent, exquisite According to the Sanskrit rucira. The Tibetan perhaps translated from a text that had cūrna (“powders”) translated as “incense.” incense, garlands, and flowers,
Make offerings always to the Jina’s stūpas
And this supreme samādhi will soon be attained.
i.
“With many kinds of excellent songs and dance,
With amusements and performances made with a pure mind,
With excellent lights and incense,
Always make excellent offerings to the unequaled one. This verse does not appear in the Gilgit manuscript or the Chinese.
“With hundreds of paṇava drums and loud mṛdaṅga drums,
With paṭaha drums, lutes, According to the Sanskrit vipañcī. Apparently replaced in Tibetan by the word sna tshogs (“various”). the excellent sound of flutes,
With the qualities of music of various kinds of melodious sounds,
Make an offering to the Guide with a pure mind.
“Create beautiful images of the Buddha,

Perfectly made of precious materials, According to the Sanskrit. The Tibetan has “wiped clean.” The Chinese has “skillfully made and adorned with precious materials,” 眾寶善巧而雕飾 (zhong bao shan qiao er diao shi).
That are attractive and extremely beautiful,
And this supreme samādhi will soon be attained.
i.
“Make excellent images that are fashioned
From gold or silver, and also sandalwood,
That are attractive and extremely beautiful,
And this supreme samādhi will soon be attained. This verse is absent in the Gilgit manuscript and the Chinese.
ii.
“Make images that are fashioned of clay,
Or stone, or wood, or painted,
That are attractive and extremely beautiful,
And this supreme samādhi will soon be attained. This verse is absent in the Gilgit manuscript and the Chinese.
“Always remain in the solitude of forests,
Forsaking the joys of villages and towns.
Be without a companion, like a rhinoceros,
And this supreme samādhi will soon be attained.
“I am the Lord of the Dharma; you are my son.
Train in this samādhi practice of mine.
I was at that time Dṛdhadatta, the world-renowned
Ruler over the descendants of Manu. Absent in the Chinese.
“Seeking this peace, this supreme samādhi,
I made offerings to countless buddhas in the past.
I always maintained pure conduct
And I honored those with the ten strengths. In the Chinese, this verse is followed by an additional verse about offerings.
“Seeking this peace, this supreme samādhi,
In the past I gave up my sons and wives.
I gave away my supreme, excellent head, legs,
Arms, and eyes without ever being disheartened.
“Seeking this peace, this supreme samādhi,
I gave away wealth and grain,
Hundreds of male and female slaves, and many jewels,
And satisfied numerous beggars.
“Seeking this peace, this supreme samādhi,
In the past I gave away great quantities
Of pearls, crystals, gold, conches, ammonite stones, Sanskrit: śila. These are ammonite shell fossils, of great significance and value in India. beryls,
Perfectly pure jewels, and a mass From the Sanskrit ghana. The Tibetan appears to have translated from a manuscript that had dhāna (“grain”). of coral,
“Seeking this peace, this supreme samādhi,
I gave away vast amounts of excellent jewelry
Of various kinds, such as perfect strings of pearls,
Lion jewelry, Sanskrit sīhanukāḥ, Tibetan seng ge can rin chen. The meaning is obscure. and nets of jewels.
“Seeking this peace, this supreme samādhi,
In the past I gave away many millions
Of fine, excellent clothes that were perfectly clean,
Made of the finest silk and cloth and beautified by gold threads.
“Seeking this peace, this supreme samādhi,
I gave away various kinds of elephants, horses, chariots,
And my own beloved sons and women,
Without ever experiencing any unhappiness.
“Seeking this peace, this supreme samādhi,
Whenever I saw people who were very poor,
Who were in distress and suffering because of their need,
I freed them from their poverty.
“Seeking this peace, this supreme samādhi,
I have in the past given to beggars
Trillions of No number in the Chinese. horses, elephants, and chariots
Draped in nets of precious jewel adornments.
“Seeking this peace, this supreme samādhi,
I have in the past joyfully and with compassion
Given away many trillions
Of excellently decorated parks.
“Seeking this peace, this supreme samādhi,
I have in the past given away beautifully adorned
Villages, towns, regions, and market towns,
And having given them felt continuous joy.
“Seeking this peace, this supreme samādhi,
I have in the past given to those who requested them
Heaps of jewels as large as Sumeru
And a similar amount of clothes and adornments.
“Seeking this peace, this supreme samādhi,
I have made those who are very poor rich,
I have protected those who were in great distress,
And I have made happy many who were enduring suffering.
“When I was a sovereign over this world
And saw the suffering of the population,
I felt compassion and wished them to be happy,
And gave my kingdom to them.
“Young man, the marvelous things that I have done,
And the hardships I have undergone for many hundreds of eons,
I would not be able to complete recounting them
Even in a quintillion eons.
“Seeking this peace, this supreme samādhi,
I underwent astonishing hardships.
The people without faith in the Sugata’s conduct
Will have minds that become crazed and polluted.
“Young man, I declare this to you:
Have faith in me; my words are not untrue.
The Sugata does not speak words that are false.
The compassionate Jina always speaks the truth.
“These many different kinds of practices

I will have carried out for many According to the Tibetan. Sanskrit: “hundreds.” eons. Chinese: “There were hundreds and thousands (or many hundred thousands) of other kinds of hardship, which I endured to the point that my body was totally exhausted.”
However I attain this supreme samādhi
I will then free millions of beings from suffering. Chinese: “How did I attain this samādhi? By freeing others from hundreds and thousands of kinds of suffering.”
“In the moment that I have attained
This samādhi, the path of great wisdom,
Having attained this supreme samādhi
I will see numerous millions of buddhas.
“I will have attained infinite miraculous powers,
And my emanations will go to hundreds of realms,
And there I will ask the compassionate ones
Many quintillions of questions.
“The sugatas will give me answers
For my quintillions of questions,
And having obtained them I will remember them all
And I will not forget even a single word.
“Having listened to the answers to those
Quintillions of correct questions,
I will teach the stainless state of peace
And establish many beings on the path of wisdom.
“I will remain in this samādhi
And train in it for many hundreds of eons,
And will first bring many quintillions of beings
On to the highest stainless path.
“Those who have not seen the previous sugatas
Who have taught this stainless way
Will not be able to have faith
In the supreme samādhi of emptiness, the ultimate truth.
“The people who have faith, are wise, and know the practice,
Are always joyful when they hear
The way that is correct and profound,
And do not become frightened or terrified.
“They hold the supreme enlightenment.
They have been reborn as my sons.
They are like fig-tree flowers,
And I practice for hundreds of eons for their sake.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Has no fear of falling into unfortunate existences,
Is always free of the eight disadvantageous states,
And will see numerous millions of buddhas.
“That one who has this supreme samādhi in his hands,
I prophesy, will have unending understanding,

And like the kind Jina According to the Sanskrit, in which, in all manuscripts, there is the adjective maitraka. The commentary glosses this as meaning Maitreya after he has attained buddhahood. The Tibetan rgyal ba byams pa grags pa mtha’ yas could be translated as “infinitely famous Jina Maitreya,” and possibly, “the Jina with infinitely famous kindness.” who has infinite fame, “infinite fame” does not appear in the Chinese.
He will accomplish many benefits for beings.
“The man who possesses this samādhi
Will have understanding and memory,
High wisdom, will retain what he has heard,
And will possess vast confidence of speech.
“The man who possesses this samādhi
Will receive the offerings of devas,
Will be continually revered by humans, According to the Tibetan, presumably translating from manuja and the Chinese人 . The Sanskrit has maruta, which is a synonym for “the devas.”

And will be constantly protected by the hosts of spirits. According to the Tibetan ’ byung po and the Gilgit manuscript bhūta. The Shastri and Hodgson manuscripts have deva. The Chinese has a combination of two words: “spirits” and “worldly gods,” 鬼神.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Does not die in fire or water,
Is not harmed by poison or weapons,
And cannot be reached by enemies.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Will always dwell in forest bowers,
Where he will be constantly attended by devas,
And where many yakṣas will be his servants.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Will have wisdom that is as vast as the ocean,
Will describe without impediment the qualities of the Sage,
And make known correctly the qualities of the Buddha.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Will have endless, boundless learning
That is beyond measure, like space,
And will hold the torch of wisdom that dispels darkness.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Will always be gentle, will speak appropriate words,
Will be beloved in the midst of his followers,
And his speech will be like the lion’s roar.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Will be like a healing physician,
The support, protector, and refuge of many,
And will bring illumination to the worlds.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Will not take pleasure in sexual intercourse. Chinese: “Does not have a mind of love and desire.”
He will enjoy śamatha and reach the bliss of dhyāna.
With a peaceful voice According to the Sanskrit gira and the Yonglé and Peking Kangyurs dbyangs. Other Kangyurs have the incorrect dbyings. Chinese: “delightful voice.” he will speak of peace.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Will not take pleasure in conceptualization,
Will be free of the entire multitude of concepts,
And that wise one will constantly be in meditation.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Will attain extraordinary vision
And will see the infinite jinas.
He will be a leader with infinite sight.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi

Will have the sweet and melodious voice of a crane, According to the Sanskrit krauñca. The Tibetan translation is khrung khrung, which usually means “the crane.” Sanskrit dictionaries normally identify this as “the curlew.” The Mahāvyutpatti has krung krung for krauñca.
The sound of the avadavat and a drumbeat, The Chinese does not have “crane,” but has “peacocks, avadavats, and various musical instruments.”
And a singing sound and gentle voice.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Will have a voice that is like resounding thunder.
His gentle speech will be like the song of a goose

And his voice will have the fifty aspects of speech. This refers to the sixteen vowels and thirty-four consonants in Sanskrit. The Chinese describes the voice as the melodious sounds of geese, bells, and drums blended with the sound of a hundred musical instruments.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Will speak with an inconceivable voice
That has the pleasant sound of the various aspects of speech
For numerous quintillions of eons.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Will not have attachment to food,
Will not delight in alms bowls or dharma robes,
But with few desires he will be content and abstinent.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Does not praise himself
And never criticizes others.
He always delights in dhyāna and has a subtle mind.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Always examines himself,
Does not look for mistakes in others,
And the entire world does not impede him.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Has pure conduct and an untroubled mind,
Is never deceitful or dishonest,
Is always gentle, and always delights in liberation.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Is always motivated to generosity,
Takes no delight in avarice,
And always has good conduct.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Is handsome, good looking, and attractive.
His body shines like the purest gold
And has the thirty-two primary signs of a great being.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Always has an attractive appearance,
Is observed and beloved by many people,
And they never have enough of gazing upon him.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Always delights, gladdens, and enchants
Devas, nāgas, and likewise the yakṣas,
Who enter towns According to the Tibetan grong. The Sanskrit has kula (“families”). and praise him. Chinese: “every family who has come to pay their respects all praise him,” 往詣家家皆讚歎.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Always has Brahmā, Śakra, and many powerful deities
Acting as his attendants,
But there is no pride in his mind.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Has no fear of the lower existences.
He has no fear of the disadvantageous existences or bad rebirths.
He is completely free of all fear of bad rebirths.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Has no doubts or uncertainties
On hearing in detail the supreme Dharma of the Buddha,
And he follows that profound wisdom.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi,
Whatever subtle Dharma teachings he hears
He attains perfect mastery of them all,
And gains their power and detailed reasoning.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Constantly thinks, ‘I will always act in accordance
With what the Jina’s words have taught,’
And attains unique, supreme retention.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Will, when the time of his death comes,
Have before him the compassionate Amitābha
And his host of bhikṣus. This verse is followed in the Chinese by an additional verse about rebirth in Sukhāvatī.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Is one who has attained the retentions,
Has perfect mastery over the treasure of the Dharma,
And possesses the unceasing words of eloquence.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi,
With peaceful conduct and a peaceful According to the Tibetan, presumably from supraśāntamana. The Sanskrit has suviśuddhamana (a pure mind). mind
Will be an illumination for beings
Wherever that holder of the Dharma goes. According to the Sanskrit, which has the singular, while the Tibetan has the plural. This verse does not appear in the Chinese.
i.
“He attains the ten bhūmis: These are taught in the Sūtra of the Ten Bhūmis (see bibliography). Perfect Joy,
Stainless, Shining, Brilliance, Difficult to Master,
Manifest, Gone Far, Unwavering,
Perfect Understanding, and Clouds of Dharma. This verse is not in any of the Sanskrit sources, nor in the Chinese, but is glossed in the commentary.
ii.
“The hero attains the ten powers: These are taught in,the Tathāgatotpattisambhavanirdeśa (“The Teaching on the Emergence of the Tathāgata”), chapter 43 in the Avataṃsaka Sūtra.

Life, According to the commentary, power over life means that the bodhisattva can remain alive for countless eons. karma, According to the commentary, power over karma means that the bodhisattva can control the time when it ripens. materials, According to the commentary, power over materials means that the bodhisattva can adorn many worlds. and devotion, According to the commentary, power over aspiration means that the bodhisattva can see all worlds filled with buddhas.

And the strengths of aspiration, According to the commentary, power over prayer means that the bodhisattva can choose the time and world of his buddhahood. miracles, According to the commentary, power over miracles means that the bodhisattva can manifest every kind of miracle. and birth, According to the commentary, power over birth means that the bodhisattva can manifest taking birth in every world.

Dharma, According to the commentary, power over Dharma means that the bodhisattva can teach every kind of Dharma. mind, According to the commentary, power over mind means that the bodhisattva is able to remain in countless samādhis. and likewise great wisdom. According to the commentary, power over wisdom means that the bodhisattva can without fear teach the understanding of all the strengths of the Buddha. This verse is not in any of the Sanskrit sources, or in the Chinese, but is glossed in the commentary.
“The man who possesses this supreme samādhi
Is skilled in the various aspects of the supreme Dharma treasure,
Has attained the perfect power of the dharmakāya,
And cuts through the doubts of all beings. This verse is absent in the Chinese.
“If all beings were compassionate bhagavāns,
And were sugatas until existence comes to an end,
And if someone were to make offerings to them for many hundreds of eons
Or for more eons than there are sand grains in the Ganges,
“And if in this latter time of destruction
Some man were to hear this samādhi
And say only the words ‘I rejoice in this!’
The previous merit would not be a fraction of this accumulation.
“Young man, whoever has this practice of peace,
This supreme samādhi, the ultimate truth of emptiness,
Propagates it and creates copies of it,
He is a dharmabhāṇaka with wisdom.”
Conclusion of the thirtieth chapter, “Tejaguṇarāja.”

div.head: Chapter 31: Benefits
div.p: Then the Bhagavān said to the youth Candraprabha, “Therefore, young man, the bodhisattva mahāsattva who thinks, ‘I shall understand the languages of all beings and, knowing their higher or lesser capabilities, I will teach them the Dharma,’ that bodhisattva mahāsattva should listen to the samādhi, the revealed equality of the nature of all phenomena , learn it, understand it, keep it, recite it to others, promote it, proclaim it, chant it, meditate on it with unadulterated meditation, promulgate it, and make it widely known to others.”
Thereupon the Bhagavān spoke these verses:
“The one who, desiring liberation, possesses this stainless samādhi
Sees the countless guides of the past,
Asks those lords of the world about their previous practice,
And that bodhisattva dwells in supreme roots of merit.
“The one who, desiring liberation, possesses this stainless samādhi
Obtains the highest happiness of devas and humans,
Obtains the supreme offerings of devas and humans,

And obtains the happiness of dhyāna, the supreme, noble happiness. According to the Tibetan. Sanskrit: “He obtains the highest happiness, the happiness of dhyāna, the noble happiness.” Chinese: “nirvāṇa.”
“The one who, desiring liberation, possesses this stainless samādhi
Does not become thrilled on hearing the highest praises,
Does not become saddened by being criticized,
And like a mountain is unmoved by the eight worldly concerns.
“The one who, desiring liberation, possesses this stainless samādhi

Speaks perfectly According to the Sanskrit akhila (“complete,” “without a gap”) and the Yonglé and Peking Kangyurs dag (“pure,” “correct”). Other Kangyurs have dge (“virtuous”). pleasantly, with gentle words,
Does not frown, always speaks sincerely,
Has a smiling face, and has been instructed by the guides.
“The one who, desiring liberation, possesses this stainless samādhi
Is pleasant, good company, has a gentle mind,
Is always restrained Chinese: “restrains the sense faculties.” and established in self-discipline,

And is very gentle, has pleasing speech, According to the Tibetan and the Shastri manuscript priyabhaṇi. Other Sanskrit manuscripts: priyavāṇi. and speaks tenderly. The Sanskrit and Chinese add “and truthfully.”
“The one who, desiring liberation, possesses this stainless samādhi
Does not quarrel or cause conflict when he speaks.
He has freed himself from all stubbornness Chinese: “pride.” and anger
And is always joyful, Chinese: “patient,” and also “he remains honest, avoids sharp language, and is lovable.” pleasant, and gentle.
“The one who, desiring liberation, possesses this stainless samādhi
Is always wise and is constantly motivated to generosity.
When he sees beings in great suffering he gives them his food;
He delights in giving to others, and not in his own enjoyment.
“The one who, desiring liberation, possesses this stainless samādhi
Is admired by a hundred thousand devas,
Is always attended by nāgas, asuras, and yakṣas,
And is protected by those who dwell in the forest and its environs. This verse is expanded into two in the Chinese.
“He speaks with unimpeded words, like the voice of Brahmā,
Has a voice like the song of a goose, a voice like a kinnara’s song, “Like a kinnara’s song” does not appear in the Chinese.
Has the fifty aspects of speech and has a sound that brings joy, Chinese: “His voice is like five hundred kinds of pleasant sounds,” 亦如五百美妙音 (yi ru wu bai mei miao yin).
And has a resounding voice, a proclaiming voice, a perfect voice. Chinese: “His fame spreads into numerous worlds,” 名聞遍彰諸世間 (min wen pian zhang zhu shi jian).
“Even if someone knew how to reduce
All the worlds into their smallest particles,
The one who possesses this supreme, stainless samādhi
Would voice sounds that were even more numerous.
i.
“The man who possesses this stainless samādhi
Attains the ten powers, and attains the eight and two bhūmis.
The wise one attains the inconceivable qualities of a buddha,

Subjugates all māras, and reaches the highest enlightenment.” This verse is in the Tibetan, and referred to in the commentary. It is in the Shastri and Hodgson manuscripts, but does not appear in the Gilgit or Chinese.
Conclusion of the thirty-first chapter, “Benefits.”

div.head: Chapter 32: The Teaching on the Nature of All Phenomena
div.p: Then the Bhagavān said to the youth Candraprabha, “Therefore, young man, a bodhisattva mahāsattva who wonders, ‘How can I know the nature of all phenomena?’ should listen to this samādhi, the revealed equality of the nature of all phenomena, learn it, understand it, keep it, recite it to others, promote it, proclaim it, chant it, meditate on it with unadulterated meditation, promulgate it, and make it widely known to others.”
Thereupon the Bhagavān spoke these verses:
“In the one who knows the peace that is the nature of phenomena
No desire arises, no anger arises,
Nor in that great leader does ignorance ever arise.
He has eliminated all kleśas without remainder.
“The one who knows the peace that is the nature of phenomena
Is a heart son of the Sugata who does not abandon the training.
He is a hero who never falls under the power of a woman.
Everywhere he rejoices in the teaching of the sugatas.
“The one who knows the peace that is the nature of phenomena
Is wise, sagacious, and knows the way of wisdom. Chinese: “he has wisdom and miraculous power,” 智慧及神足 (zhi hui ji shen zu).
He sees infinite, endless buddhas

And knows infinite dhāraṇīs According to the Sanskrit and the commentary. The Tibetan in all Kangyurs has gzugs in error for gzungs. and wisdom. Chinese: “he knows dhāraṇīs and has reached the other shore” (or “the way to reach the other shore”), 總持到彼岸 (zong chi dao bi an).
“The one who knows the peace that is the nature of phenomena
Will before long become a lord of humans.
He knows the skills of healing and bestows happiness, Chinese: “he knows how to cure kleśas.”
And he is able to remove all the pain of suffering. Chinese: “he is skilled in removing poisonous arrows.”
“The one who knows the peace that is the nature of phenomena
Knows that sentient beings are suffering.
He always beats the drum of the elixir.
He will before long become a guide. The Sanskrit adds: “and a jina.” This verse does not appear in the Chinese.
“He is the supreme physician, skilled in healing.
He knows the origin of all illnesses and how to be freed from them.
He has wisdom and trains correctly.
Having trained he liberates many lost beings.
“The one who knows the peace that is the nature of phenomena
Is a wise hero who is skilled in the nature of emptiness.
He has no attachment to the world and always his food is alms,
And he brings many beings to supreme enlightenment. This verse does not appear in the Chinese, which has another verse about the quality of non-attachment and being worthy of offering.
“The one who knows the peace that is the nature of phenomena Chinese: “the skandhas are empty in nature.”
Is a moon Chinese: “lion.” among men, superior through the power of patience.
He is not angry even if struck with stones and sticks,
And he is not disturbed even if his limbs are severed.
“The one who knows the peace that is the nature of phenomena
Has the strength of being established in the strength of patience. Chinese: “The strength of his patience is as vast as Mt. Meru.”

Not seeing a thing that is tolerated, he is perfectly at peace. The Degé and other Kangyurs of the tshal pa group have the verb of this sentence as mi gtong, (“not letting go”), which would not make much sense. The Stok Palace Kangyur has mi mthong (“not seeing”), closer to the sense of the Sanskrit and the commentary.
He is a wise hero who does not become proud of the strength of his patience. In the Chinese this verse is followed by an additional verse concerning knowing the three times and the three realms.
“The one who knows the peace that is the nature of phenomena,
Never has in mind the idea ‘I am cutting through things;’
For him all things are nonexistent, always empty,
And he has eliminated every single conceptual identification.
“Such are they who teach the supreme nature of phenomena.
They will before long reach the highest enlightenment.
They comprehend the scope of the nature of phenomena.
They give a gift that is infinite and endless.
“The one who knows the peace that is the nature of phenomena
Teaches infinite millions of sūtras
That are more numerous than sand grains in the Ganges,
And there is no interruption in their eloquence.
“The one who knows the peace that is the nature of phenomena
Has wisdom as high as Sumeru,
Constantly for a hundred trillion eons,
And his teaching of the Dharma knows no end.
“The one who knows the peace that is the nature of phenomena
Has a vast, abundant, inconceivable eloquence.
He constantly seeks supreme enlightenment
And teaches infinite millions of sūtras.
“The one who knows that these phenomena have no substance
Perfectly hears and remembers the entirety
Of the Dharma that the lords of humans have taught
And does not doubt even a single word.
“The one who knows that phenomena are always empty
Is at all times uniquely superior in his generosity.
He is a patron who gives happiness to those who suffer.
When he sees beings suffer he satisfies them with jewels.
“The one who knows that phenomena are always empty
Will always become the king of Jambudhvaja.
At all times he has love for all the living
And always brings infinite happiness to beings.
“The one who knows that phenomena are always empty
Is a hero who gives away his sons, daughters, and slaves.
That great leader’s mind never wavers,
As he gives away his hands, his feet, his head, and his kingdom.
“The one who knows that phenomena are always empty
Has no anger in his mind, even in a dream,
Even though his limbs are cut from his body;
For him it is an offering to the guides, the lords of humans.
“The one who knows that phenomena are always empty
Makes offerings to all the guides of the past,
Makes offerings to the lords of humans in the future,
And venerates all the guides in the present.
“The one who hears and retains this sūtra in the degenerate times
Is a wise man who possesses the treasure of the sugatas.

He is established in the supreme retentions, These are, according to the commentary, the four retentions (dhāraṇīs), which might mean either of the two sets of four (see glossary). The commentary has gzugs (“forms,” or “bodies”) in error for gzungs.
And before long will become a guide of the world.
“The one who does not forget but teaches this sūtra
Is a wise man who will never become blind.
Throughout many eons he will not lose a limb,
And will always avoid the eight disadvantageous states.
“He will never be reborn in the lower existences.
He will always have a beautiful body with the primary signs of a great being.
He will always cultivate the five higher cognitions,
And that hero will always be in the presence of the sugatas.
“Endowed with wisdom he will manifest many emanations
That will go to millions of realms to guide beings.
Of all those who see this multitude of buddha emanations,
That many beings will be brought to supreme enlightenment.
The one who hears and retains this sūtra in the degenerate times
Will be endowed with memory, understanding, wisdom, and constancy.
He will become powerful through the strength of his diligence.
He will have great brilliance and he will reach the culmination of the Dharma.
i.
The one who holds this samādhi of peace in the degenerate time
Is a hero established in the brahmavihāras.
He quickly attains the eight and two bhūmis,
And swiftly subjugates the māras. The Sanskrit has “ten million māras.” This verse is present in the Tibetan, and the Shastri and Hodgson manuscripts, but absent in the Gilgit and Chinese.
ii.
He who always meditates on this sūtra of peace
Will attain power and possess the highest strengths.
He will always be one who is intent on benefiting beings,
And will realize the highest enlightenment at the foot of the Bodhi tree. This verse is present in the Tibetan, and the Shastri and Hodgson manuscripts, but absent in the Gilgit and Chinese.
“Those who meditate that these phenomena are empty
Constantly radiate ten billion light rays
And eclipse even the discs of the suns.
Those heroes will, before long, become guides of the worlds.
“In the past I practiced this field of peace
For many quintillions of eons.
My diligence upon this path was unceasing
And Dīpaṃkara prophesied I would become a jina.
“You also should follow my practice of this sūtra,
This teaching that leads to the profound ultimate truth.
There are many tīrthikas who are lost in error concerning this.
They revile enlightenment and fall into the terrible lower realms.
“During many quintillions of eons
They will experience unendurable sufferings of heat.
And even after many millions of eons have passed
They will still not die for that reason.
“Those who in the terrible latter times
Protect this sūtra of the Sugata, this state of peace,
Will attain the highest enlightenment without difficulty.
They are the prophesied holders of the Dharma in the future.”
Conclusion of the thirty-second chapter, “The Teaching on the Nature of All Phenomena.” Conclusion of fascicle 6 in the Chinese.

div.head: Chapter 33: The Benefits of Possessing the Sūtra
div.p: Then the Bhagavān said to the youth Candraprabha, “Therefore, young man, the bodhisattva mahāsattva who wishes to train in purifying According to the Tibetan byi dor bya ba yongs su sbyang ba. The Sanskrit parikarmadhāraya could be translated as “maintaining or gaining the preparation for.” the great higher cognition of all phenomena should listen to the samādhi, the revealed equality of the nature of all phenomena, learn it, understand it, keep it, recite it to others, promote it, proclaim it, chant it, meditate on it with unadulterated meditation, promulgate it, and make it widely known to others. This paragraph is in a simpler form in the Gilgit and Chinese.

“Young man, what is the purification of the great higher cognition of all phenomena? It is having no grasping toward all phenomena, it is having no clinging to the aggregate of conduct, See also note 938. [add crossrefs.] it is having no pride in the aggregate of samādhi, it the absence of movement in the aggregate of wisdom, it is having the discerning insight According to the main classical meaning of vivekadarśana and its description and translation, or gloss, in the commentary as de bzhin nyid mthong ba. The Tibetan translates according to its alternate meaning of “separation,” dben pa. of the aggregate of liberation, and it is seeing correctly as it is the aggregate of the insight of the wisdom of liberation. The five “aggregates” mentioned here are the “five undefiled aggregates” (Tibetan zag med kyi phung po lnga, known in Sanskrit according to Mahāvyutpatti 103 as the “five aggregates of those equal to the unequalled ones” asamasamapañcaskandhaḥ). See glossary under “aggregate of conduct.” The Gilgit manuscript adds here “insight into the empty nature of all phenomena,” which is absent in the later Sanskrit manuscripts and the Tibetan.
“The bodhisattva mahāsattva who has those higher cognitions manifests all the manifestations of samādhi and teaches the Dharma to beings.
“This, young man, is what is called ‘the purification of the great higher cognition of all phenomena.’ ”
Then at that time the Bhagavān gave a detailed Dharma teaching on purifying the great higher cognition of all phenomena by chanting the following extensive verses to the youth Candraprabha:
“The purification of the great higher cognitions
Is an incontrovertible teaching.
Someone who practices in contradiction to it
Will not become free of attachment.
“That higher cognition, that wisdom,
Is the inconceivable wisdom of buddhahood.
Someone who remains in attachment
Will never know that wisdom.
“The numerous inconceivable Dharmas
Are taught by using words.
Someone who is attached to words
Will not know the meaning of the teaching.
“How can someone teach the meaning
Who does not know the meaning behind the words?
Someone who has not learned what the true nature is
Teaches that which is not the Dharma as the Dharma.
“The one meaning of the differing words
Of the sūtras that have been taught by me
Within thousands of worlds
Is something that cannot be stated.
“Through contemplating a single word
All of them will be meditated on—
All of the many kinds of Dharma that have been taught
By however many buddhas there have been.
“For people who have mastered the meaning
That all phenomena are selfless, According to the Tibetan of the commentary, the Sanskrit, and the Chinese. The Tibetan of the sūtra has “emptiness.”
When they have learned this word

The Dharmas of the Buddha will not be hard to attain. According to the Sanskrit na durlabhāḥ and the Chinese. The Tibetan has dkon ma yin (“are not rare”), perhaps in a scribal error of dkon for dka’.

“All phenomena are the Buddha’s Dharma. There is a play on words here that is lost in translation, as phenomena and the Buddha’s teaching are both called “dharma.” The commentary explains that this is because the nature of phenomena (dharmatā) is such that no phenomenon ever transcends its nature of emptiness.
They who have learned the nature of phenomena,
They know the nature of phenomena
And do not contradict the nature of phenomena.
“All words are the Buddha’s words,
As all words have no substance.
Although one seeks them in the ten directions
The words of the Buddha will not be found.
“These words are the Buddha’s words.
Though one seeks them in the ten directions,
These unsurpassable words are not to be found.
They have never been found and never will be found. This verse does not appear in the Chinese.
“The Buddha’s words are unsurpassable.
There is nothing higher than the Buddha’s words.
There is not an atom of them that is to be found,
And that is way they are called unsurpassable.
“An atom, a phenomenon, is not produced.
Although explanations use the term ‘atom,’
Something the size of an atom cannot be found;
It is a term used in teaching on the worldly level.
“The unfindability of phenomena is found,
But that finding also cannot be found.
Thus the one who knows phenomena
Realizes the highest enlightenment,
“And having realized the highest enlightenment
He will turn the wheel of the Dharma.
Through turning the wheel of the Dharma
He teaches the Buddha’s Dharma.
“The bodhisattvas who realize
The highest wisdom of buddhahood,
Because of that are called buddhas,
As they have realized buddhahood’s wisdom.
“The absence of existents, the absence of aspiration,
The absence of attributes, and emptiness—
It is these doorways to liberation
That the Buddha taught as doorways.
“The eyes, the ears, and the nose,
The tongue, the body, and likewise the mind,
The buddhas have explained
That they are by nature empty.
“The one who knows in that way
The nature of phenomena,
Knowing the characteristics of phenomena,
He will not be in disagreement with it.
“This the realm of experience of the heroes,
Of the bodhisattvas, the protectors.
They know the emptiness of phenomena
And they never have any doubt.
“He who knows the nature of phenomena,
He is called a buddha.
He guides countless, innumerable
Beings to enlightenment.
“That which is accomplished by the word buddha
Is also accomplished by the words correct conduct.
The words buddha and correct conduct
Have the same characteristic.

“However many According the commentary and the Sanskrit yāvanta. The Tibetan ’ jig rten (“worldly”) in the sūtra may be a translation of a corruption in a Sanskrit manuscript. Chinese: “various.” words are spoken
Whether superior, middling, or lesser,
They are all taught in the one word meditation,
And in the one word buddha.

“The Buddha’s Dharma According to the commentary, the Sanskrit, and the Chinese. The sūtra’s Tibetan has sangs rgyas sgra (“the word buddha”), perhaps translating from buddhaśabda in error for buddhadharma. Also, throughout this passage, Dharma is in the plural, meaning “the numerous Dharma teachings,” though rendered here into English as singular. is stated
To have no location and no direction.
It has no birth and no cessation.
Neither is it single nor multiple.
“It is not new and it is not old.
There is nothing to be proud of.
It is not blue and it is not yellow;
Neither is it white, nor red.
“That which is taught through verses
Is inexpressible and ungraspable.
This miraculous activity of the Sage
Is beyond the level of verses.
